list_definition.definition: coiled round like a spring, with each coil the same size as the one below
winding round and round, usually tapering to a point
an increase or decrease, or rise or fall, becoming more and more rapid (eg in prices).

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: A spiral of smoke rose from the chimney.

list_definition.definition: to go or move in a spiral, especially to increase more and more rapidly

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Prices have spiralled in the last six months.

list_ex_of_english: One of the characteristics of the discourses to be constructed under such a system is the production of "perpetual spirals of power and pleasure" (45).
In its shell guise, the spiral usually has small protuberances around the perimeter.
The circularity was planned in the spiral design of the house to express a sense of the infinite, impossible to evade.
This rest increases the physiological changes occurring in the body and the fatigue experienced in a selfperpetuating spiral of increasing fatigue.
Stationary and drifting spiral waves of excitation in isolated cardiac muscle.
He drew the line on a brown paper envelope - it spiralled around a circle.
By 1988 the monetary indicators were spiralling out of control.
However, spiralling wage demands, growing unrest and strikes continued.
